SENT.plain: DNA polymerase eta (pol η) is the only DNA polymerase causally linked to carcinogenesis in humans
Inherited deficiency of pol η in the variant form of xeroderma pigmentosum (XPV) predisposes to UV-light-induced skin cancer
Pol η-deficient cells demonstrate increased sensitivity to cisplatin and oxaliplatin chemotherapy
We have found that XP30R0 fibroblasts derived from a patient with XPV are more resistant to cell kill by ionising radiation (IR) than the same cells complemented with wild-type pol η
This phenomenon has been confirmed in Burkitt's lymphoma cells, which either expressed wild-type pol η or harboured a pol η deletion
Pol η deficiency was associated with accumulation of cells in S-phase, which persisted after IR
Cells deficient in pol η demonstrated increased homologous recombination (HR)-directed repair of double strand breaks created by IR
Depletion of the HR protein, X-ray repair cross-complementing protein 3 (XRCC3), abrogated the radioresistance observed in pol η-deficient cells as compared with pol η-complemented cells
These findings suggest that HR mediates S-phase-dependent radioresistance associated with pol η deficiency
We propose that pol η protein levels in tumours may potentially be used to identify patients who require treatment with chemo-radiotherapy rather than radiotherapy alone for adequate tumour control
